author: Emily Payne for MailOnline
title: Disney Parks set to introduce on-demand pricing based on queue sizes
text:
2
View
comments
Disney has announced it will make changes to pass prices at its theme park, but the amount you'll spend or save will depend entirely on the size of queues at each attraction.
Last year alone, Disney Parks saw more than 134 million visitors, so considering an on-demand pricing structure isn't a hugely surprising decision.
After all, anyone who has visited the parks on a Saturday or during a holiday knows just how busy it can get during peak times.
Is this the happiest place on Earth? To help deal with huge demand during peak holiday times, Disney Parks is considering on-demand pricing
In an attempt to regulate attendance, Disney Parks will be raising prices on its annual passes and enforcing blackout dates.
The Signature Plus pass, which allows entrance any day of the year, will now cost $1,049 (£682.52), but if you opt for the same pass with 15 blackout dates, the price substantially decreases.
Instead, it will offer Mickey Mouse enthusiasts a pass for just $849 (or £552.41).

Share this article Share And the limited Deluxe pass, which has even more blackout dates at popular times of the year, has now increased in price to $599 (£389.75).
'We have to look at ways to spread out our attendance throughout the year so we can accommodate demand and avoid bursting at the seams,' Walt Disney Parks and Resorts Chairman Bob Chapek said in a statement.
By raising the price of its annual passes - and introducing more blackout dates - Disney hopes to balance attendance during not-so-popular times
